The  Project  will  improve  rural  livelihoods  through  nationwide 
financing  of  investments  in  participatory  small-scale  water 
resources management, including flood management, drainage 
improvement,  water  conservation,  and  command  area 
development  (includes  activities  to  improve  surface  water 
irrigation  such  as  providing  field  channels  and  pipe  systems), 
benefiting  209,000  ha  of  cultivable  land.  It  will  directly  benefit 
324,400  households  (about  1.7 million  people)  through  more 
intense cropping systems, increased culture fishing areas, and 
greater crop and fish yields. For the three sample subprojects, 
over  80%  of  direct  beneficiaries  were  poor.  The  estimated 
poverty impact ratio (the percentage of the net financial benefits 
plus  the  economic  surplus  flowing  to  poor  households  divided 
by  the  total  net  financial  benefits  and  economic  surplus)  is 
calculated  at  0.65.  The  economic  rate  of  return  for  the 
subprojects ranges from 26% to 28% and for the overall Project 
it  is  29%.  Flood  management  and  drainage  improvement 
subprojects are also expected to reduce damage to public and 
private infrastructure significantly and to contribute to measures 
to  adapt  to  climate  change.  Requiring  WMCA  management 
committees  to  have  a  one-third  representation  by  women  will 
raise  the  status  of  women  in  the  community  and  encourage 
women  to  participate  in  income-generating  activities  and 
employment.

Performance Indicators and Analysis 
With  a  population2 of  over  150  million  living  in  an  area  of  147,570  square  kilometers 
3. 
(1,045  persons  per  square  kilometer),  Bangladesh  is  one  of  the  most  densely  populated 
countries in the world. About 80% of the population lives in rural areas and is mainly engaged in 
agriculture  and  related  nonfarm  activities.  More  than  two-thirds  of  the  rural  population  is 
landless  or  functionally  landless  (owning  less  than  0.2  hectares  [ha]  of  land).  The  national 
poverty  headcount  ratio  declined  from  56.6%  in  1991  to  48.9%  in  2000  and  further  to  40%  in 
2005.3 The rural poverty rate is now between 44% and 53%.4 Bangladesh has limited land and 
other natural resources, and a high population density. As a result, rural poverty is pervasive.  

Bangladesh has achieved impressive economic and social gains over the past decade, 
4. 
including GDP growth of 5%–6%, relatively low inflation, and fairly stable domestic debt, interest 
rates, and exchange rates. Its growth has been remarkably resilient despite numerous natural 
disasters and some erosion in business confidence. Real gross domestic product (GDP) growth 
in  FY2008  remained  strong  at  6.2%,  supported  by  more  domestic  economic  activity  in  the 
second half of FY2008. Human poverty trends have improved more quickly than income poverty 
trends. The human poverty index (based on deprivations in health, education, and nutrition) was 
61% in the early 1980s, declined to 47% in the early 1990s and dropped further to 35% in the 
late 1990s. The index of human poverty has declined annually by 2.5% compared with a 1.5% 
decline in the poverty headcount ratio for income poverty since late 1980s.5 

5. 
Despite this progress, Bangladesh remains one of the world’s least developed countries 
with  GDP  per  capita  of  $555  (FY2008),  poverty  incidence  of  up  to  53%,  and  a  48%  child 
malnutrition  rate  (footnote  5).  Although  agriculture’s  share  of  GDP  (about  20%)  has  been 
declining  as  the  economy  grows,  it  remains  the  primary  economic  sector  in  rural  Bangladesh 
and provides 63% of rural employment. Food crops represent about 72% of the value added by 
agriculture, followed by fisheries (11%), livestock (10%), and forestry (7%).

Poverty  in  Bangladesh  is  primarily  rural  and  has  many  dimensions.  Women  are  more 
7.

living in remote and vulnerable areas such as riverbanks (footnote 3). Meeting the MDG target 
for poverty reduction will require a sustained GDP growth rate6 of 4% in agriculture and 7% in 
the nonfarm sector, a formidable task. 

8. 
Water  resources  management.  Bangladesh  faces  significant  physical  challenges 
because of its flat topography7 and its location at the confluence of three major transboundary 
rivers—the  Brahmaputra,  the  Ganges,  and  the  Meghna.  On  average,  20%  of  the  country 
experiences monsoon flooding over banks and faulty drainage. Severe flooding with about 60% 
of  the  country  under  water  occurs  about  every  decade.  Periodic  natural  disasters  (including 
cyclones  and  tidal  surges)  and  dry  season  droughts  have  severe  impacts  on  agriculture, 8 
fisheries,  and  livelihoods  of  people  living  in  affected  areas.9 Greater  use  of  groundwater  for 
agriculture  and  consumption  and  its  deteriorating  quality  (specifically  arsenic  contamination  of 
over 30% of groundwater resources10) has serious implications for health, soil degradation, and 
agricultural  yields.  Bangladesh  needs  to  reduce  its  reliance  on  groundwater  by  improving  the 
management  of  surface  water  through  flood  management,  drainage  improvement,  water 
conservation,  and  by  improving  the  reliability  and  efficiency  of  irrigation  supplies  in  command 
areas.11

Food security. Since early 1980s, Bangladesh has achieved near self-sufficiency in rice 
production from a chronic food deficit. Since 2000, per capita food grain production has grown 
by 1.3% per year and agriculture’s growth target for 2009 is 4.0%, up from 3.6% in 2008. Total 
cultivable land for aus and aman rice increased by 17% in 2008. Despite these achievements, 
food  security  remains  vulnerable  particularly  in  years  when  production  is  affected  by  natural 
disasters12 and (as witnessed in 2008) dramatic increases in world food prices. The price of rice 
in the international market rose by 196% (from $325 per ton in May 2007 to $963 per ton in May 
2008).13 In  April  2008,  the  retail  price of  coarse  rice  increased  by  61%  to  Tk32.1  per  kilogram 
(kg) from Tk19.9/kg in April 2007.14 However, by September 2008, the rice price had fallen back 
to $686 per ton—still 110% higher than the 2007 price.

Food price surges (mainly for rice) in 2008 seriously eroded the purchasing capacity of 
people  living  below  the  poverty  line.  According  to  a  2008  study15 on  the  weighted  inflationary 
impact  of  the  price  of  rice,  an  additional  8.5%  of  households  (2.5  million  households  or  12

food crop production is critical to tackling rural poverty. Efforts to increase food grain production 
need to be continued to keep pace with population growth and to ensure food security for the 
poor. Providing effective and sustainable water management infrastructure is an important part 
of this effort.

A. 

Benefits and Impacts 

57. 
The Project will improve rural livelihoods through the nationwide financing of investments 
in  participatory  small-scale  water  resources  management,  including  flood  management, 
drainage  improvement,  water  conservation,  and  command  area  development,  benefiting 
209,000 ha of cultivable land. It will provide direct benefits to 324,400 households in the form of 
intensification  of  cropping  systems,  increased  culture  fishing  areas,  and  greater  crop  and  fish 
yields.  Up  to  230  subprojects51 will  be  supported  and  an  additional  150  SSW  1  and  SSW  2 
subprojects will  be  provided  with  technical  and institutional support  for  low-cost,  quick-yielding 
benefits. The Project will generate significant social and economic benefits, including improved 
living  conditions  and  livelihood  opportunities  for  communities  living  in  flood-risk  and  drought-
prone  areas.  Flood  management  and  drainage  improvement  subprojects  are  also  expected  to 
reduce damage to public and private infrastructure significantly and to  contribute to adaptive52 
measures for climate change.  

During the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA), a comprehensive study was 
58. 
carried out at three subprojects, which were selected to represent53 about 230 small-scale water 
resources  schemes  throughout  the  country.  The  study  indicated  that  these  subprojects  would 
deliver  agricultural  benefits  that  met  local  needs  and  priorities.  Environmental,  social,  and 
poverty impacts were expected to be positive. Over 80% of subproject beneficiaries in the three 
subproject areas were small, marginal, or landless farmers. The estimated poverty impact ratio54 
was calculated at 0.65, which is reasonable considering the proportion of land operated by large 
or medium-sized households.

Financial Analysis 

59. 
Crop  and  fisheries  budgets  were  prepared  for  individual  subprojects  and  with-  and 
without-project  scenarios  were  compared.  Significant  revenue  from  the  subprojects  will  be 
derived  from  making  the  land  more  productive  by  reducing  submergence  during  the  monsoon 
season  and  drought  in  winter.  New  crop  technologies  will  help  to  diversify  cropping  patterns, 
increase  cropping  intensities,  and  improve  yields.  The  move  from  local,  traditional  varieties  of 
rice  to  high-yielding  aman  and  boro  rice  significantly  improves  yields.  Improved  cropping 
technologies usually result in a need for more labor at a higher rate, generally $4–$5 per day, 
providing  a  solid  incentive  for  farm  families  to  invest  in  the  Project.  Incremental  employment 
generated  by  subproject  activities  (for  the  entire  Project)  is  estimated  to  be  118,000  person-
days,  of  which  about  30%  will  be  incremental  labor  by  women.  The  average  incremental  net 
agricultural  income  per  household  covered  by  the  Project  will  increase  by  up  to  68%.  Small, 
marginal,  or  landless  households  will  receive  up  to  46%  of  the  financial  benefits  at  full 
development. Financial internal rates of return (FIRR) estimated for the sample subprojects are 
robust,  ranging  from  20%  to  27%,  reflecting  their  ability  to  recover  investment  and  operating 
costs.  The  estimated  financial  benefit–cost55 ratio  is  1.4  and  the  overall  project  FIRR  is  28%.

2. 

Economic Analysis 

60. 
The  economic  analysis  has  drawn  together  project  investment  costs  over  an  8-year 
implementation  period,  including  recurrent  costs  needed  to  ensure  sustainable  benefits,  and 
compares them with the quantified incremental benefits over a 20-year period. Crop production 
benefits  will  result  mainly  from  increased  yields,  the  greater  area  of  less-flood-prone  land, 
adoption of higher-value crops, more irrigation and improved agricultural practices, as detailed 
above. Fisheries production, a small part of the benefits, will be maintained. Land use changes 
will  result  in  an  increase  in  cropping  intensities  rather  than  in  the  cropped  area.  The  current 
overall cropping intensity is 161% and this is expected to increase to 173%, with the boro area 
increasing from 69% to 76% of the total cropped area. The Project will produce 56% more aman 
rice than currently and increases of 33% in aus and 29% in wheat.  

In 2008, world cereal markets were volatile, supplies were tight, and demand was rising, 
61. 
making the market sensitive to shocks. Mean rice prices in 2008 were $650 per ton, compared 
with prices of $286 in 2005, and $580 in January 2009.56 World Bank price projections show the 
real price of rice falling back to $404 per ton from 2010, although this is still higher than in 2007. 
This  gives  rice  a  conversion  factor  ranging  from  0.8  to  1.5,  depending  on  the  world  price 
adopted. Using 2010 prices, the conversion factor is 1.0, which is used in the economic analysis. 
For the sample subprojects, economic internal rates of return (EIRR) range from 26% to 28%, 
giving an overall project EIRR of 29%. Switching values indicate that the Project is sensitive to 
delays  in  benefits,  although  it  remains  economically  viable  at  14%  with  a  2-year  delay.  The 
Project is insensitive to increased investment cost, crop production, or O&M costs.

Social Benefits 

62. 
The Project is expected to make significant contributions to poverty reduction in project

It is estimated that poor households will receive 46% of the total financial benefits at full

household  income  and  food  production  improve  the  nutritional  status  of  the  populations  in  the

labor  for  the  earthworks  involved  in  project  construction  is  likely  to  be  drawn  from  local  poor 
households.  Women’s  participation  in  WMCAs,  which  includes  their  one-third  membership  of 
the  management  committee,  will  provide  benefits  from  employment  opportunities  created  and 
other services provided to WMCAs (see poverty analysis in Supplementary Appendix L).

Background and Issues 

1. 
Bangladesh is in an alluvial deltaic floodplain in the confluence of three major rivers—the 
Ganges, Brahmaputra, and Meghna. These rivers have a catchment area of 1.74 million square 
kilometers (km2) and display substantial seasonal variability of flows, leading to severe flooding, 
sedimentation,  and  riverbank  erosion,  causing  social  hardship  for  the  rural  poor.  Flooding  is 
seasonal and there is often drought in the dry season. Coastal and estuarine areas suffer from 
saline intrusion and associated environmental degradation as well as periodic cyclones and tidal 
surges—further exacerbated by climate change impacts. Arsenic contamination of groundwater 
is widespread, resulting in significant health implications. Water management is complicated by 
the  diverse  livelihood  activities  of  rural  poor,  including  agriculture,  fisheries,  transportation, 
industries,  and  water  supply.  Community  participation  for  integrated  and  strategic  water 
resources  management  is  critical  for  sustaining  rural  livelihoods  and  safeguarding  poor  from 
flooding impacts.

development,  (ii)  an  enabling  framework,  and  (iii)  agriculture  and  water  management  for

development  and  the  enabling  environment,  along  with  urgent  investment  programs.  The 
NWMP  priorities  include  (i)  promotion  of  rational  management  and  optimal  use  of  water

A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
Contribution of the Small-Scale Water Resource Development subsector to reduce poverty in Bangladesh:  
The  National  Strategy  for  Accelerated  Poverty  Reduction  (NSAPR)  II,  2009–2011  identified  the  interface  between 
water  resources  management  and  poverty.  It  notes  the  impact  of  global  climate  change  and  identifies  water 
resources  development  and  management  as  a  critical  sector  for  achieving  pro-poor  economic  growth  and  food 
security  through  agricultural  development.  The  NSAPR  II  emphasized  managing  demand  and  supply  during  dry 
season,  reducing  disasters  during  wet  season,  carrying  out  operation  and  maintenance  of  infrastructure,  building 
additional  irrigation  facilities,  establishing  water  pricing  principles,  incorporating  environmental  considerations,  and 
carrying  out  institutional  capacity  development  for  water  management.  It  also  stressed  the  creation  of  income-
generation opportunities for the poor through water resources management.   
The  Project  follows  two  similar  projects,  the  first  and  second  Small-Scale  Water  Resources  Development  Sector 
Projects  (SSW  1  and  SSW  2)  and  is  consistent  with  NSAPR  II.  Effect  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  those  projects 
revealed significant incremental agriculture production, which is critical to the livelihoods of the poor and to mitigate 
the  current  food  crisis.  Surveys  and  field  visits  at  sample  subproject  sites  indicated  that  the  Project  is  expected  to 
generate substantial temporary employment in construction and long-term employment associated with the increase 
in  agricultural  and  fisheries  production.  The  Project  will  attempt  to  address  the  poverty  of  beneficiaries  living  and 
farming  in  subproject  areas  by  small-scale  water  resource  development  that  will  provide  (i)  drainage,  (ii)  flood 
management, (iii) water conservation, (iv) command area development, and (v) institutional development. The main 
employment window for the rural poor will be in seasonal construction and as sharecroppers.  
ADB’s Country Strategy and Program (CSP) for Bangladesh, 2006–2010, identified expansion of access to irrigation 
and  associated  flood  protection  through  command  area  and  small-scale  water  resource  management  as  a  key 
strategy.  The  CSP  also  emphasized  building  country  capacity  and  ensuring  community  participation  (especially  by 
the  disadvantaged  and  women)  in  designing  and  implementing  projects.  The  Project  is  consistent  with  the  CSP. 
Water  management  cooperative  associations  (WMCA)  will  be  formed  in  each  subproject  area  by  the  beneficiaries 
and  about  one-third  of  the  members  of  WMCAs  will  be  women.  The  WMCAs  will  eventually  be  responsible  for 
operation and maintenance of the infrastructure to ensure that project benefits are sustainable. The WMCAs will bring 
all types of beneficiaries under a single umbrella, ensure participation of various groups, and ensure benefits accrue 
to these groups, especially the poor and vulnerable. The WMCA will also be oriented and trained on operation and 
maintenance of the infrastructure.

A.  Findings of Social Analysis 
Initially,  the  Project  will  reduce  the  incidence  of  floods  and  create  dry  season  irrigation  facilities  through  water 
conservation  schemes.  Participatory  and  sustainable  small-scale  water  resource  management  will  improve 
agricultural  and  fisheries  production,  benefiting  the  entire  community  in  the  subproject  area.  The  farmers  (large, 
small, medium, and marginal) will directly benefit from the increased productivity and increased agricultural coverage 
as a result of reduced  water logging and flooding as  well  as increased irrigation opportunities. Fisheries production 
will increase because of the development of water control and management structures. The potential benefits of poor 
and vulnerable men and  women  will be both direct and indirect and  will include: (i) direct employment opportunities 
created  under  the  Project  for  construction  of  water  management  infrastructure;  (ii) increased  employment 
opportunities  in  the  agricultural  and  fisheries  sectors  due  to  incremental  production;  and  (iii) productive  skills  and 
possible microfinance as members of WMCAs as per the poverty reduction plan. An empowerment process will begin 
because of the participation of the poor and vulnerable in the decision making process of the WMCAs.  
1.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
The  beneficiaries  of  the  catchments  area  of  each  subproject  suffer  either  from  water  logging,  flooding,  drought  or 
from lack of irrigation opportunities. The crop intensity is low and often crops are damaged. The beneficiaries need 
support  to  make  the  best  use  of  their  land  and  other  assets  free  from  flooding  and  drought.  They  need  flood 
management,  water  conservation,  drainage,  command  area  development,  jobs,  access  to  capital  and  productive 
skills  for  livelihood  support.  The  WMCAs  will  provide  a  platform  to  increase  the  participation  of  the  poor  and 
vulnerable in community development decisions.

A. 

Approach and Methodology 

1. 
The  basic  assumptions  used  for  economic  analysis  include  the  following:  (i)  the  world 
price numeraire was used; (ii) base costs and benefits are in June 2008 terms with conversion 
factors to adopt domestic prices to international prices; (iii) Bangladesh taka (Tk) was the unit of 
account (the exchange rate used is for 2008, when Tk68 = $1); (iv) a standard conversion factor 
of  0.91  and  a  shadow  wage  rate  of  0.9  for  unskilled  labor  were  used;  (v)  economic  values  of 
major  tradable  commodities  were  based  on  border  parity  pricing  and  standard  methods  of 
deriving  farmgate  output  and  input  prices  were  applied;  and  (vi) transfer  payments  such  as 
taxes and subsidies were excluded in the calculation of economic values. 

For  each  of  the  three  sample  subprojects, 1  estimates  of  cropping  patterns  and 
2. 
technologies in the with-Project and without-Project scenarios were based on expected changes 
in land use due to flood protection and/or increased availability of water for crops. Per hectare 
costs of production and returns for relevant crops were calculated and translated into economic 
values.  For  the  subprojects’  net  benefited  area,  the  incremental  value  of  production  was 
calculated. Some subprojects (for example Goshinga) may be expected to have an effect upon 
capture  fisheries.  Operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs  were  estimated  at  6%  of 
construction  costs  for  earthworks  and  0.5%  of  the  cost  of  structures.2 Benefits  and  costs  are 
expressed  as  cash  flow  streams  over  an  expected  20  years  of  subproject  life  from  which 
economic  and  financial  internal  rates  of  return  (EIRR  and  FIRR)  are  calculated.  Sensitivity 
analyses were performed by assuming various scenarios relating to particular risk factors such 
as  shortened  project  life  due  to  poor  O&M,  delays  in  project  benefits,  increased  construction 
costs,  decreased  benefits,  and  rice  price  fluctuation.  Agricultural  production  benefits  are 
generally  assumed  to  accrue  to  landowners  and  operators.  Household  income  is  expected  to 
increase  from  incremental  labor  utilization  with  the  subprojects.  Improved  water  resource 
regimes  allow  farmers  to  more  fully  adopt  technology  for  high-yield  varieties  and  labor  inputs 
can be expected to rise to some extent. In local financial terms this increase in labor income can 
add substantially to household income, particularly that of the poor.

Economic  benefits  were  calculated  from  the  incremental  value  of  crop  production 
4. 
generated  by  the  subproject,  net  of  production  cost  at  economic  input  and  output  prices. 
Livestock  benefits  were  included  by  valuing  fodder  and  crop  residues.  Fishery  benefits  were 
modeled  directly  for  canal,  flood,  and  fish  pond  activities  but  were  small  compared  with  crop 
benefits  (about  10%  of  total  benefits).  Project  benefits  excluded  from  the  analysis  included 
improved  navigation  in  drainage  canals,  environmental  and  health  benefits  from  improved 
nutrition,  and  better  water  management  and  drainage.  The  area  of  cereal  crops  grown  will 
remain more or less constant at around 143,000 ha but cropping intensity will increase because 
of land use changes and flood management, leading to an anticipated overall increase of 34% 
in  paddy  rice  production.  Current  overall  cropping  intensity  is  161%  and  this  is  expected  to 
increase to 173% with the boro area increasing from 69% to 76% of total cropped area.  

Paddy rice production dominates agricultural production and rice is a major food product. 
5. 
Bangladesh  imports  rice  when  export  item  harvests  are  poor  due  to  climatic  events.  This 
situation is expected to continue in the medium term. No problem is envisaged in marketing the 
increased rice production. Incremental project rice production has been valued on the basis of 
its farm gate equivalent price. The estimated export parity farm gate price for paddy was Tk18 
per kilogram (kg) in January 2009  (using a world price of $580 per ton), and the import parity 
price was Tk23 per kg. This compares with a support price of Tk17.5 per kg. Domestic paddy 
rice prices usually lie somewhere between export and import parity levels as most rice is used 
domestically and only a small proportion is traded. Mean rice prices in 2008 were $650 per ton, 
compared  with  $286  in  2005,  and  $580  in  January  2009.3 World  Bank  price  projections  show 
the real price of rice falling back to $404 per ton from 2010, but this will still be higher than 2007 
levels. This gives rice a conversion factor ranging from 0.8 to 1.5, depending on the world price 
adopted.  Using  2010  price,s  the  conversion  factor  is  1.0,  and  this  was  used  in  the  economic 
analysis.  

6. 
Other grains were a minor part of the market. Bangladesh is currently a net importer of 
wheat. Long-term wheat prices are expected to fall below 2007 values, but wheat prices have 
been  relatively  stable,  even  in  2008.  Calculated  wheat  prices  were  based  on  world  prices  for 
wheat  in  2010  at  import  parity.  The  farm  gate  price  was  Tk23.3  per  kg,  compared  with  the 
support price of Tk29.1 per kg, giving a conversion factor of 0.8. 

Prices  of  inputs,  especially  fertilizer,  rose  dramatically  in  the  first  6  months  of  2008. 
7. 
Fertilizer  prices  are  being  driven  by  rising  demand  associated  with  biofuel  production,  and  by 
the rising price of oil. In Bangladesh, the cost of production of urea is reported to be Tk50,000 
per ton ($735), while the Government has set the farm gate price (June 2008), at Tk12,000 per 
ton ($176). Thus, the subsidy on urea is Tk38,000 per ton or 76% of production costs. Prices in 
2008  were  well  above  the  long-term  trend  line,  but  are  currently  declining.  Prices  reported  by 
the  World  Bank  commodity  price  series  were  used.  Future  prices  were  based  on  the  most 
recent  available  price  forecast  (November  2008).  The  domestic  financial  price  of  urea  is  very 
low. Even at 2007 prices, a conversion factor of 2.5 is required, and a conversion factor of 3.5 is 
required  if  mean  2008  world  prices  are  used.  The  detailed  economic  and  financial  analysis  in 
Supplementary  Appendix  K  shows  that  forecast  urea  world  prices  are  expected  to  fall  below 
2007  prices  in  real  terms,  while  it  is  likely  that  large  domestic  subsidies  will  be  maintained.  A 
long-term conversion factor based on forecast 2010 prices, of 2.2, looks most realistic, and was 
used for the analysis.
